quote: Computer, download file to PADD...    (checking its serial     number)    F-seven.
Download complete.
You're up late.
I have a few things to finish up    before I leave in the morning.
I'm presenting a paper at a    medical conference.
I see. Where is it? Risa,    Casperia Prime?
Casperia. How'd you guess?
Doctors always hold their    conferences at sunny resorts.
Ours can be a grim profession.    Don't you think we deserve a break    from all the illness and death?
Don't forget to bring plenty of    sunscreen.
Let me guess. You dislocated your    shoulder.
Not again.
You promised me you wouldn't go    kayaking again until your shoulder    had a chance to heal.
I know. But I can't stay away.    (trying to explain     himself)    It's like the river calls to me.
That's right. It's saying, "Stay    away. Don't come near me. I'll    only hurt you more!"
Much better.
It'll be tender for a few days so    go easy on it.
Right.
If the pain starts to get any    worse, Nurse Bandee can give you    something.
Thanks, Julian. Have a good time    on Casperia.
I'm going to a medical conference,    not on a vacation.
Whatever you say.
Remember -- listen to the river...    and stay away.
The time is oh-seven hundred hours.
You're joking. Computer,    confirm time.
The time is oh-seven-hundred    hours, twenty-three seconds.
Something tells me I'm going to    need a lot of raktajino today.
See you in a few days, old chum.   Keep the home fires burning.
Attention, senior officers.   Report to Operations immediately.
What now?
This better be quick. I have a   transport to catch.
What's going on?
Internal Affairs.
What are they doing here?
They're not saying.
(trying to lighten the     mood)   If they'd called ahead, we   could've thrown them a party.
Something tells me this isn't a   social visit.
Where is the captain?
(motioning to Sisko's     Office)   In there.
He doesn't look very happy.
No. He doesn't.
All right, people. This is Deputy    Director Sloan of Internal    Affairs. He's here under the    authority of the Federation    Council. I expect you to give him    your full cooperation.
Starfleet Intelligence has reason    to believe that there's been a    security breach aboard Deep Space    Nine.
It appears that someone has been    passing information to the    Dominion.
With all due respect, I think    there's been some kind of mistake.
I hope you're right, commander.    I really do.
But until we determine the source,    we have to follow standard    containment procedures and isolate    the members of the senior staff.
As of now, you're all relieved of    duty and confined to quarters.
Confined to quarters?
I don't like it any more than you do.
You'll be contacted shortly. I'll    be conducting interviews with each    one of you. For the time being,    you're not to discuss this matter    amongst yourselves.        Any questions?
Do you have any idea how long your    investigation is going to take?
It's difficult to say, doctor.    But don't worry, we've already    contacted Starfleet Medical and    informed them that you won't be    attending your conference.
How very considerate of you.
Take them to their quarters.
Would you follow me, please.
Hot buttered scones, moba jam and    red leaf tea.
What's wrong with this thing?
Come in.
Would you please come with me,    doctor?
Certainly.
Where are we going?
To the wardroom. Director Sloan   wants to ask you some questions.
Stand clear --
What's going on?
Nothing you need to worry about,   sir.
This way.
Doctor Bashir.
Have a seat.
I'm sorry you had to miss your   medical conference, but it    couldn't be helped. In a case    like this, I have to follow strict    procedures.
Of course. I understand.
Maybe it's a blessing in disguise.        The last time you tried to attend    a medical conference you were    taken prisoner by the Dominion.
An experience I wouldn't care to    repeat.
I'm sure you wouldn't. Five weeks    in a Dominion prison camp -- I    can't imagine what it must've been    like.
It wasn't pleasant.

I read your report.    (with a hint of     admiration for Bashir's     fortitude)    It made me ask myself how I    would've held up under those    conditions. I guess you never    really know until you go through    it.
I'm sure you would've found a way    to cope. We do what we have to to    survive.
I was just reading some of your    case reports. Fascinating stuff.    The work you did with those    genetically enhanced patients?    Very impressive.
Thank you.

Before you started working with    them, they were described by    Starfleet Medical as --       -- "alienated, uncommunicative,   and hostile." You're the first   doctor who managed to establish a   dialogue with them.
Well, I think the fact that I'm    genetically enhanced myself made    them more open to accepting me.
You spoke their language.
Exactly.
I envy your profession. You make    a positive impact on people's    lives.        You know, I considered becoming a    doctor myself.
You have a good bedside manner.        When I walked in here, I was half    expecting to be interrogated under    a bright light.
Not this time.
Well, I don't see a need to    trouble you any longer. Thank you    for your cooperation.
My pleasure.
Lieutenant Chandler will take you    back to your quarters. I'm afraid    I'm going to have to ask you to    stay there until I've finished the    rest of the interviews.
In that case, could you send    someone to have a look at my    Replicator? It isn't working.
Actually, we took them off-line.
Oh?
To prevent anyone from trying to    replicate a communications device    or a weapon.
All I want is some breakfast.
What would you like? I'll have it    sent to your quarters right away.
Hot buttered scones, moba jam and    red leaf tea.
Coming right up.
Thank you.
Doctor. One more thing.
Yes.
About those genetically enhanced   patients of yours. Did Starfleet   Medical ask you to work with them,   or did you volunteer?
I volunteered.
I see, very good.
Yes.
Here you are, sir.
Thank God. I'm famished.
Cheers.
Enjoy.
Ugh. It's a little too early for   gag'h.
I hope you like scones, Worf...
Miles? Sloan said we aren't    supposed to talk to each other.
I just wanted to make sure you    were all right.
I'm fine. Except I think    someone's been snooping around my    quarters.
Wouldn't surprise me. Has Sloan    questioned you yet?
We just finished.
How did it go?
He asked me a few routine    questions. It went fine.
Believe me, it's not fine. He    grilled me for over two hours.
Two hours? About what?
About you.
You're joking.
I only wish I were. But every    single question was about you.
I'd better go before they trace    this transmission. I just wanted    to warn you to watch your back.
Miles, wait. What did he want to    know about me?
Just be careful. I think they're --
Come in.
Director Sloan wants to see you.
Again?
That's right.
Did you get your breakfast,    doctor?
Yes, I did.
Good.
I was going over my notes from our    last conversation and there are a    few things I'd like you to    clarify.
Oh?
Do you have a problem with that?
Not at all.
Let's go back to the time you    spent with the Dominion.
I wasn't "with the Dominion." I    was their prisoner.
You were held at Internment Camp    Three-Seven-One?
Yes.
Barracks Six?
Correct.
And you were there five weeks?
Thirty-seven days, actually.
Are you absolutely sure?
Yes.
And General Martok was with you in    Barracks Six?
That's right.
He said that the Jem'Hadar removed    you from the barracks.
I complained because they cut our    rations, so they put me in    solitary confinement.
I see, and did you meet with    anyone during that week?
I was alone.
Are you sure?
Let me think. Was I alone in    solitary? Yes. I think I was.
You didn't meet with a Vorta?
No.
Or a changeling?
No.
So, you're telling me that you    spent seven days in complete    isolation?
Not seven. Five. Five days.
That's odd. General Martok said    you were gone for seven days.
Well, he's wrong. It was five.
Why would he lie about something    like that?
He's not lying.
You can't both be right.
All I'm saying is that he must've    lost count of the days. He was    under a lot of stress at the time.
And you weren't?
Human beings tend to be better at    adapting to incarceration than    Klingons.
Especially if they're genetically    engineered.
Meaning what?

Let's move on to the matter of    your escape from the camp. I'll    quote from your own report.        "We constructed a transmitter    using components from the    barracks' life-support system. We    used it to contact our runabout    and beam ourselves out of the    camp."        Forgive me, doctor, but that    sounds a little hard to believe.
It's what happened.
Why would the Dominion leave your    runabout orbiting the camp    unattended?
They didn't expect us to be able    to contact it.
Why not? They left you everything    you needed to build a transmitter.
Isn't it more plausible that the    Dominion wanted you to escape?
Why? For what reason?
So that you could start working    for them.
I'm not working for them.
How can you be sure?
Excuse me?
How can you be sure that you're    not working for them? Are you    familiar with the term engramatic    dissociation?
Vaguely.
The theory holds that if a    person's mind is sufficiently    disciplined, he'd be capable of    compartmentalizing contradictory    information -- believing one thing    while doing another.

I think you possess that kind of    mind. I think the Dominion saw   that and decided to take advantage    of it. I think they broke you and    turned you to their cause, then    had you suppress the memory of    what happened.
You're saying I'm a Dominion spy    and I don't even know it?

What could be more perfect?    There's no chance of your getting    caught because you don't even    realize you're working for them.    When they're ready to debrief you,    all they have to do is trigger    your memory.
That's ridiculous.

Doctor, I'm trying to help you,    but I need your cooperation. I    need you to tear down the walls    inside your mind and dredge up a    fragment of memory -- anything    about your mission, your contacts.    I know it's not easy, but you've    got to try.

There are no memories to dredge    up. I am not suffering from    engramatic dissociation. I am a    loyal Starfleet Officer, and I am    not going to answer any more    questions unless I'm formally    charged and can respond with the    benefit of counsel.

I've had enough of your lies,    doctor. You think you're smarter    than the rest of us, don't you?    Smarter than the millions of brave    men and women who are putting    their lives on the line for the    Federation.        You want to do things the hard    way? Fine. But I'm going to get    the truth out of you. And when    I'm done, I'm going to take    whatever's left of you and lock it    away.        Guards.
Is it really necessary to drag a   Starfleet Officer across the   Promenade in irons?
We have our orders, sir.
Please stand aside.
We're going to get you out of   this, Julian.
I'm sure it's all a mistake.       Isn't it?
Where's Odo?
(enjoying Bashir's     discomfort)    In his quarters. We'll be    handling security for the time    being.
(smiles re: the     manacles)    Too tight?
A bit.
You'll live.
I'm glad to see you enjoy your    work.
I was with the Seventh Fleet when    the Dominion attacked the Tyra    System. Ninety-eight of our ships    were destroyed in a matter of    hours. I lost a lot of friends.
I lost friends there, too.
I believe that, but yours were    Jem'Hadar.
You won't be needing this anymore.
Step inside.
With all due respect captain, if    you'd just wait in the Security    Office, Director Sloan should be    here any minute and you can    discuss your request with him...
There's nothing to discuss. I    want ten minutes alone with my    officer, and I want them now.
Very well.
I thought you should know that Odo    did some checking. Sloan had a    son in Starfleet -- a transport    pilot. He was killed by a    Dominion patrol.
Maybe he thinks I supplied the    information that helped them    target his son's ship.
That's exactly what I think.
When my son's convoy dropped out    of warp to rendezvous with a    Klingon bird of prey, they found    three Dominion attack ships    waiting for them instead.
I'm sorry for your loss. But    don't you think your son's death    indicates a conflict of interest    with your investigation?
I like to think that it gives me    an added incentive to get to the    truth. Now what is it you want?
I need to talk to my chief medical    officer in private.
I can understand that. But    security protocols require that no    one speak to the prisoner without    clearance from me.
Director Sloan, have you received    orders from Starfleet to relieve    me of command of this station?
No, I haven't.

Then as long as I'm in command,    I'll see Doctor Bashir whenever I    please. Furthermore, from now on    I'll sit in on all interrogation    sessions to make sure that his    rights are observed. Do I make    myself clear?
I believe so.
Well then, we'll see each other    tomorrow.        In the meantime, I'll leave you to    your conversation.
I appreciate your help, sir.
We'll get this straightened out,    I promise you.

-- let's go back a few years to    the incident at Bopak Three.    According to your report, you and    Chief O'Brien "crash-landed" on    the planet, where you then made    contact with a group of Jem'Hadar.
We didn't "make contact." They    captured us.
If that's the case, why didn't you    attempt to escape?
We didn't have the chance.
According to Chief O'Brien, you    were more interested in trying to    cure the Jem'Hadar of their    addiction to Ketracel White.
I'm a doctor. They were suffering    from withdrawal.
They're the enemy -- genetically    engineered killing machines.
They're not machines, they're    sentient beings. I couldn't just    stand by and watch them die.
Why? Because you felt sympathy    for them -- being genetically    engineered yourself?
This is irrelevant. You're    talking about an incident that    took place before Doctor Bashir    allegedly became a Dominion agent.
It's not irrelevant, Captain. If    anything, it shows that he was    already sympathetic to the    Dominion.

(picking up another    PADD)   Let's move on.        Doctor, we spoke yesterday about    a group of genetically enhanced    patients that you brought to the    station. Why, exactly, did you    decide to work with them?
They'd been institutionalized most    of their lives. I thought I might    be able to help them assimilate    into society.

A laudable goal. But what I find    puzzling is the way you went about    it. These misfits had been    sheltered from the outside world    for as long as they could    remember, yet you chose to bombard    them with information about the    war with the Dominion. Frankly,    I'm surprised it didn't scare them    into deeper isolation.
I was trying to engage them--- and    it worked.
Is that why you convinced    Starfleet Command to give them    access to classified battle plans?
Starfleet was interested in    hearing our ideas on how to win    the war.
How to win the war? You    recommended that the Federation    surrender!
We were looking for a way to save    as many lives as we could. If    you'd take the time to examine our    findings --
Captain, you took the time to    examine their findings, didn't    you?
I did.
Did you agree with them?
No.
Of course not. No loyal Starfleet    officer could.
I won't deny that Doctor Bashir    has made some...    (choosing his words     carefully)    -- questionable decisions in his    career, but you're a long way from    convincing me he's a traitor.
So far, your case is based on    circumstantial evidence and    speculation.
What other kind of case can I make    against a man who's covered his    tracks so well?
That's a circular argument and you    know it.

Captain, if Doctor Bashir had been    involved in one or two    questionable incidents, I can    understand how you might be able    to dismiss them. But the sheer    number of incidents form a pattern    of behavior that can't be ignored.

I understand that you want to be    loyal to a man who's served under    you for so long. I understand    that you're inclined to take his    word over that of an outsider.    But step back for a moment and    think about it. This man    concealed the truth about his    illegal genetic enhancement for    over thirty years. He lied to get    his medical license. He lied to    get into Starfleet. He lied to    you when he came aboard this    station and he's lied to you ever    since.
He did eventually come forward and    tell the truth.
That's right, he did. But why?        What made you confess, Doctor?    Was it because you realized it was    your duty to be honest with your    captain?
Was it because you felt guilty    about having lied to him for so    long?
No.
Then why did you come forward?
Because I'd been found out.
And if you hadn't been found out?    Would you have come forward and    told your captain the truth...    ever?
I don't know.
I see.
Sloan's right about one thing,    sir. I should have told you the    truth about me from the beginning.
That's right. You should have.    But lets put that behind us for    now.
How am I supposed to defend myself    against this man? No matter what    I say, he either thinks I'm lying    or repressing my memories.
I know you're not lying, Julian.
But?
As a doctor, isn't it within the    realm of medical possibility that    the Dominion did recruit you --    and that you have blocked it out    of your memory?
Even if it was possible, it didn't    happen.
You don't believe me.
I don't think you're lying.
It's late. Try to get some sleep.    We'll talk again in the morning.
Sorry to interrupt your sleep,    doctor. It looks like you're    going on a little vacation after    all.
Where are you taking me?
To Starbase Fifty-three for    further questioning.
Where's Captain Sisko? Does he    know about this?
It's none of his concern. Not    anymore.
You have no right to do this.
Oh, but I do...

Starfleet Special Order Six-Six-   Seven-One-Five, gives me authority    to neutralize security threats to    Deep Space Nine by "whatever means    necessary."        Doctor, you're about to spend the    rest of this war in a maximum    security cell. Unless...
... you'd care to add your    thumbprint to this confession.    (off Bashir's outraged     stare)    We can reword it if it doesn't    meet your exacting standards.
You can take your confession and    toss it out the nearest airlock.
I thought so.        Take him to the shuttle.
Please place your hands in front   of you.
He's beaming out! Stop him!
Good evening, Doctor.
Weyoun... ?
Welcome home.
It would appear we got you out    just in time...
It's all right. You're among    friends now.        Did they mistreat you? I don't    see any bruises.
Why did you bring me here?
What choice did I have? Starfleet    discovered you were working for    us.
(trying to convince     himself as much as     Weyoun)    I'm not working for you. I am not    a Dominion spy.
You actually believe that, don't    you? That's why you're such a    good operative.
You're lying.

Here we go again. These little    conversations of ours always    follow the same pattern: You    start out confused. Then you get    angry. Then you deny everything.    Until finally the walls inside    your mind start to break down and    you accept the truth.
(not wanting to believe    it)   What truth, that you broke me when   I was in the prison camp?

We're not barbarians. There was    no torture involved. We simply    helped you to see that there's no    way Starfleet can defeat the    Dominion. And because you didn't    want billions of Federation    citizens to lose their lives    needlessly, you agreed to provide    us with information that would    help us end the war quickly. You    rose above the petty question of    which "side" you were on and made    a moral decision. It's not    suprising, really. After all, you    are a doctor.
You're saying that I am a    traitor...

"Traitor," "Hero" -- those are    just words. Oh, your friends on    Deep Space Nine may vilify you,    but history will judge you to be    a great man -- a visionary who    helped bring about an end to one    of the most devastating wars the    galaxy has ever seen.
But... I don't remember any of    it... I don't remember...
Of course not. You suppressed the    memories -- compartmentalized    them.
A remarkable ability, but it does    make these initial conversations    a bit wearing.
Have something to eat. You always    re-integrate better on a full    stomach.
Do you remember the first time I    offered you scones? Back at the    camp?
No.

(leans forward,     urgently)    Concentrate. Sensory details are    the key. I had you brought in    from solitary. You were very    hungry, but you refused to give me   the satisfaction of seeing you    eat.        Do you remember?
No. I don't remember. I don't    remember because it never    happened.
You were almost there. Try again.    With just a little more effort you    can break through.
I am not a Dominion spy!
I can see this is going to be one    of our more difficult sessions.
I'm innocent -- I don't care what you    or Sloan think.
Wait a minute. You're both trying    to convince me of the same lie --    how could that be? Unless you're    working together.
Please, Doctor. Listen to    yourself.
Sloan is the traitor --
Combat Stations! Enemy ship    approaching!
Sisko.
I'm afraid we're going to have to    continue your debriefing later.
Let's get out of here.
Away Team to Defiant. We have    him.
I suppose you have a perfectly    reasonable explanation for why the    Dominion broke you out of that    holding cell.
I realize how it must look, sir.
What did they want, doctor?
Weyoun tried to convince me that    I was his operative. I think he    and Sloan are working together.
That's enough. You're not going    to exonerate yourself by casting    suspicions on someone else.
Maybe he's not a traitor, maybe    he's been replaced by a    changeling. All I know is that he    and Weyoun are trying to frame me.
You have run out of excuses,    doctor.
I'm innocent -- you have to    believe me.
I've had enough of your lies,   doctor.
Sir, you can't just dismiss what   I'm saying. If I'm right, there's   no telling what damage Sloan could   do --
Get him off my bridge.
Let's go, doctor.
Jadzia, you believe me, don't you?
Why'd you do it, Julian?
Miles, not you.
Your shoulder. It's all right.
Of course it's all right.
But you dislocated it yesterday...    when we were playing springball.
So it's better now.
You didn't hurt it playing    springball, you were kayaking in    a holosuite.
You're not Miles.
And you're not Captain Sisko --    he'd at least be willing to hear    me out.
This isn't real... it can't be...
You're right, Doctor. None of it    was real. But I am. And this    isn't over.
Congratulations, doctor. It's not    often that we're proven wrong.
I take it you finally believe I'm    not working for the Dominion.
I'm leaning heavily in that    direction.        But to erase any lingering doubts --   what do you say we make one final    test?
I'm finished playing games with    you, Sloan.
I assure you, doctor, this is no    game.
Don't be afraid. I have no    intention of hurting you. I just    need to remove an implant from    behind your right ear.
I'll tell you what... why don't    you do the honors?    (to the guard, re: the     extractor)    Give it to him.
Go ahead, Doctor. It's only a    neuro-synaptic relay.
You've recorded my neuro-electric    responses?
That's correct. And now I'd like    to check the findings in order to    confirm what I already believe --    that you're an innocent man.        Now either you remove the relay...    or we will.
Thank you. This'll only take a    moment...
Take your time. I don't seem to    be going anywhere.
I'm glad to see your sense of    humor returning. That's a very    good sign.
Of what?
That you're beginning to relax...
We had to subject you to high    levels of stress to ensure    accurate test results.        And I'm glad to say the results    are in your favor.
Your loyalty to the Federation    appears to be above reproach.
Do I still detect a note of doubt    in your voice?

Frankly, I would've preferred to    have kept you under observation a    little longer.        Unfortunately, we didn't know    about Chief O'Brien's injury or we    would've incorporated it into the    program.
I take it you beamed me into this    holosuite from my quarters, while    I was asleep.
I believe we allowed you a full    hour.
No wonder I felt so tired. I    suppose you find your subjects    more malleable when they've been    deprived of sleep.
Not a new technique, I admit, but    an effective one nonetheless.
So, are you going to tell me who    you are? Who you work for?
I would think it's obvious -- the    same people you work for. The    Federation. Starfleet.
You don't expect me to believe    you're with Internal Affairs, do    you?
Of course not. Internal Affairs    is a competent department, but...    limited.
Then what department are you with?
Let's just say I belong to another    branch of Starfleet    Intelligence... our official    designation is Section Thirty-one.
Never heard of it.
We keep a low profile. It works    out better that way... for all    concerned.
And what does "Section Thirty-one"    do -- aside from kidnapping    Starfleet officers?
We search out and identify    potential dangers to the    Federation.
And once identified?
We deal with them.
How?
Quietly.
So if I had turned out to be a    Dominion agent -- what would've    happened to me?
We wouldn't be standing here    having this conversation.
And Starfleet sanctions what    you're doing?
We don't submit reports or ask for    approval for specific operations,    if that's what you mean. We're an    autonomous department.
Authorized by whom?
Section Thirty-one was part of the    original Starfleet charter.
That was two hundred years ago.    Are you telling me you've been    operating on your own ever since?    Without specific orders?    Accountable to nobody, but    yourselves?
You make it sound so... ominous.
Isn't it? If what you say is    true, you function as judge, jury    and executioner. I'd say that's    too much power for anyone.
I admit it takes exceptional    people to do what we do -- people    who can sublimate their own    ambitions to the best interests of    the Federation.         People like you.
Me?
You have all the qualifications to    be a very useful member of Section    Thirty-one.
A few minutes ago, you were    calling me a traitor... now you    want to recruit me?
You're intelligent, resourceful    and you've always been fascinated    by covert operations. Why else    would you spend so much time in    Quark's holosuites playing a spy?
You're serious.
We're on the same team. We    believe in the same principles    that every other Federation    citizen holds dear.
But you violate those principles    as a matter of course.
In order to protect them.
I'm sorry. But the ends don't    always justify the means.
Really? How many lives do you    suppose you've saved in your    medical career?
I don't see what that has to do    with anything.
Hundreds... thousands? Do you    suppose that those people give a    damn that you lied to get into    Starfleet Medical? I doubt it.

We deal with threats to the   Federation that jeopardize its    very survival. If you knew how    many lives we've saved, I think    you'd agree that the ends do    justify the means.    (trying to seal the    deal)   I'm not afraid of bending the   rules every once in a while -- if   the situation warrants it. And I   don't think you are either.
You've got the wrong man, Sloan.
I don't think so. In time, you'll    come to agree with me.
Don't hold your breath.
All I ask is that when you get    back to Deep Space Nine, you    consider what I've said.
What makes you think I'm not going    to try to expose you?
Let's just say... I'm not going to    lose any sleep over it.
I'll say one thing for this fellow    Sloan, he's clever. He timed the    Doctor's abduction to coincide    with his trip to the medical    conference. That way, he wasn't    missed.
He's a clever one all right...

We went over Julian's quarters but    we didn't find any residual    transporter signatures. They    either got him off the station    some other way, or they have    Transporter technology we can't    detect.
Captain, any word from Starfleet    Command about Sloan or Section    Thirty-one?
There's no record of a Deputy    Director Sloan anywhere in    Starfleet. As for Section Thirty-   one... that's a little more    complicated.
Starfleet Command didn't    acknowledge its existence. But    they didn't deny it either.
They simply said they'd look into   it and get back to me.
When?
They didn't say.
Sounds like a cover-up to me.
Is it possible that the Federation    would condone this kind of    activity?

Personally, I find it hard to    believe that they wouldn't. Every    other great power has a unit like    Section Thirty-one... the Romulans    have the Tal Shiar, the    Cardassians had the Obsidian    Order...
But what would that say about us?    That we're no different than our    enemies? That when push comes to    shove, we're willing to throw away    our principles in order to    survive?
I wish I had an answer for you,    Doctor.
Maybe we should do some more    checking... try to track down    Sloan ourselves.
It won't be easy. If what he says    is true, and Section Thirty-one    has existed since the birth of the    Federation... they've learned to    cover their tracks well.
We don't have to find them.    They'll come to us.
You said Sloan wanted to recruit    you.
I turned him down.
He doesn't strike me as a man who    takes "no" for an answer.        And next time he asks you to join    his little group... you'll say    "yes."
I can hardly wait.
Congratulations, Julian. Looks    like you're going to get a chance    to play a spy after all.        Only this time, for real.
